### Description

The `bulma/sass/utilities/derived-variables.sass` file extension was changed in version `0.9.0` from `.sass` to `.scss`, therefore breaking imports unless using the `/utilities/_all.sass` import.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In a file where you are customizing your local Bulma settings, import the derived variables file as: `@import '~bulma/sass/utilities/derived-variables.sass';`

The file extension for `bulma/sass/utilities/derived-variables.scss` should not need to be changed in order to upgrade to version 0.9.0. File extension for this single file should be reverted back to `.sass`. 

### Actual behavior

Importing the `bulma/sass/utilities/derived-variables.sass` file, as a standalone file, fails.

Issues.Title: Spacing Docs description wrong and Helpers refactor
Issues.Body:
This is about **the Docs**.

The new Spacing docs says in the subtitle:
"Change the size and color of the text for one or multiple viewport width"

.. but that doesn't make sense for those utilities.

Also, I think the "Visibility" helper section should really be renamed or split out into Visibility and Display.  Having `is-flex` and other such helpers under Visibility doesn't make sense IMHO; they can be used and likely are used much more for layout/display than for showing/hiding items.

1. View Changelog at https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#090 to check for breaking changes

Issues.Title: RTL support
Issues.Body:
This PR adds RTL support to Bulma.

A new file `bulma-rtl.css` exists. It's built through setting the new flag `$rtl` to `true`.

Most directional properties have been replaced with one of these 4 new mixins `+ltr` `+rtl` `+ltr-property` and `+ltr-position`. I decided not to use logicial properties like [`margin-block-start`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/margin-block-start) because their support is still too low.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "RTL support" (#2983)

Issues.Title: [WIP] Optional CSS Variables and themeing ability
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->
<!-- DO NOT REBUILD THE CSS OUTPUT IN YOUR PR -->

Over the years, there have been tons of demands and tries to get css variables into bulma
https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/issues/1775
https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/issues/2749
https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/issues/1837

This PR does this successfully with a lot of ingeniosity by maximizing backward compatibility, the framework can be compiled exactly like before with no css variables, it can be compiled with all the css variables for outside theming or it can be compiled with a set of themes for bundled theming

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is a **new feature**.
<!-- New feature? Update the CHANGELOG.md too, and eventually the Docs. -->

### Proposed solution
Wrapping every variable in a few custom functions and to register them all beforehand
A theme mixin to output the used variables and the modified ones on successive call

I also revisited the build process from a simple cli command to a more complete nodejs binary

### Tradeoffs
The only tradeoff of this solution is that because of the wrapping of each variable, the git diff is large and will cause a lot of merge conflicts and will require future PR to follow the new syntax (though it's not a hard syntax, just slightly repetitive)
There will also be a minor BC break because some variables have been modified (Mainly the map `$colors` and the map `$shades` that are now only a list of names)
The other variables will stay compatible as long as you build without theming enabled (by default)

### Todos
- [x] Check that the HSL transformation corresponds to the output of lighten, saturate and adjust-hue
- [ ] Update doc
- [ ] Add a theme switcher in the doc
- [ ] Update changelog
- [ ] Cleanup and remove files according to guidelines

<!-- Thanks! -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "[WIP] Optional CSS Variables and themeing ability" (#2981)

Issues.Title: Feature request: is-borderless helper
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**.

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**.

### Description

It would be great if there was an `is-borderless` helper to accompany `is-shadowless` and `is-paddingless`.

Use case: I have some blockquotes on my site that are displayed within cards, and that creates a double border that looks bad.  Adding an `is-borderless` class would be a quick way to clean that up.

https://bulma.io/documentation/modifiers/helpers/
